title: What will life be like in 2020? - Quora

response.answer_text: Very complex issues will be laid bare as costs meet reality and the consumers realize they cannot bear the burden. Politicians in the news will be replaced in the mainstream media. Commercial marketing will set it's sights on infrastructure commercialism and “patriotism” will be required to cover the costs. Hollywood will adjust their revenue streams accordingly. Switching the revenue streams from carbon fuels to smaller distributed generation inter-connectivity will demand RE-designing the electrical grids. Less line loss as runs become shorter and advanced AI can react to balance the grids. This may take another 2 election cycles to get the campaign financing sources adjusted. EVs will be sought out by most families and the parking lots at work, home and shopping centers will become the RE-fueling stations and connected to the grids. The utility companies figure out they can make money selling the small power to EVs and retail businesses they generated by covering acres of parking lots and didn't lose in transmission. The good thing with this is the muscle car and badass trucks sales will be a very specific slice of buyer and will be much more focused. War machinery will throttle back as smaller platforms become more powerful, more versatile and more expensive. America and China may agree to disagree and get to work on moving the human race forward instead. Of course we have to elect real legislators who focus on commerce not BS. Entitlement programs will decrease as patriotism and infrastructure jobs are created using the same competing taxpayer funding. Career paths in the trades will pay more than managerial positions in manufacturing. By the way, manufacturing will depend upon 20th-century energy sources and the labor supply will build new energy-efficient and disaster-resistant housing within the range of the EVs that will take over the highways. SpaceX and Boeing will push the interstellar colonization and seek out one-way specialists who are nearing retirement age as returning to Earth's gravity after a year+ will not be an option physically. Huge wealth will be found in new sources of resources to support energy storage and creation. Consumers will realize they are healthier than told and that healthcare was really just a power grab by unseen rogue trillionaire puppeteers. But the puppets had better cut their strings

My clients at two scenario planning companies frequently asked this kind of question. Our answer was that no one can know the future for sure, but the best way to be prepared is to preview the set of worlds that could be created if the strongest forces in the present were stretched to their possible (not just probable) extremes by the target date. It then helps to build a plausible narrative around those extremes and ask yourself how you could respond if they start to happen. At Global Business Network we would list 20-50 drivers or forces that were shaping the present but also undergoing change themselves. Demographics are changing, but they are predictable, baked in by birth and death rates. All versions of the near future will have pretty much the same demographics. Of the things that are uncertain, which ones are most influential? It is also critical to limit the context. The future of healthcare, energy, government, or China? Very different answers to these questions. Let's take ground transportation as an example. The economics of electric vehicles are changing rapidly. Car makers have already announced plans that defy their earlier lethargic response. Self-driving breakthroughs are not quite as rapid and they face regulatory constraints but they are also occurring rapidly. Car sharing/ownership changes are also ripling through the economy. Can we construct four stories that describe where these forces could take us by 2020? Already been done. The informal consensus is that it is more useful to go out just a bit further, say 2023, for the changes to really take hold. Actually building the scenarios is a bit beyond a Quora answer, but it has been done and will continue to be revised as changes in the forces occur. What about war with North Korea? Wouldn’t that invalidate all the transportation scenarios? Yes and no. Best way to tell is to develop both transportation and war scenarios and see how they interact. The process is both an art and a science, not the easiest to learn to do well, but worth the effort.

It’s really hilarious that optimism about 2020 prior to the year. Nobody even expected this year to be of turmoil and huge global crisis due to Covid-19 virus. Also the lockdown in most countries as well as canceled events globally or postponed to next year (like Summer olympics and UEFA Euro 2020). This year will be that year economic upheaval takes place (especially post-corona) with a possible economic depression. Also the disease also exposed the weakness of neo-liberalism which has been the political and economical paradigm (that political parties shifted towards both politically and economically) since the end of the cold war and the fall of USSR. Neo-liberalism economical policies has it’s roots in the 80’s economical boom and emulating it. It’s basically “make profits at all costs” no matter of the long term effects. Even the socialism-aligned parties (especially social democrats) as well as conservative-aligned parties aligned onto neo-liberalism, which not at least created several shortages seen in the public sector (like lack of vital medical supplies for the covid-19 patients). I think there will be a new political and economical paradigm that will replace neo-liberalism in the post-corona era. And this is from a EUROPEAN point of view and NOT american (USA) point of view, since USA has always have that political paradigm by default in a very extreme way (no matter republican or democrat) and we can see that USA is the country that has the disease hardest strucked at because the whole healthcare system is privatized. In Europe (as well as Canada) there is room for shifting towards a more stable public sector (as well as a political and economical paradigm) that can withstand crisis with the magnitude of covid-19/corona. Also, another note is that I think USA will be declining in the post-corona era and China and EU will rise

Let’s play it safe by comparing innovation in the 2020’s what happened a century earlier, back in the 1920’s. What we can anticipate is refinement & mainstream adoption of technologies that are already in existence today. Electric Vehicles: They’re already here - we’re seeing them on the roads more & more often, and they’re becoming more affordable for consumers. The rollout of electric vehicles seems to be very similar to the advent of gas automobiles back in the horse & buggy age. At first, lots of horses, then the occasional automobile, and before you know it everybody’s driving a Model-T. Well, same difference, but now it’s Tesla. Medical Wearables: People are living longer & more independently than ever, meaning that medicine will continue to become more important - and medical wearables will fill a valuable need for medical & emergency monitoring of seniors while they hold on to their lifestyle independence. Think “Apple Watch”. Cryptocurrency: There are a zillion reasons why you’d want a fully digital replacement for cash, especially one not intrinsically tied to a single national government. PayPal demonstrated the need, but it has limitations - now PayPal is one of the partners in Facebook’s Libra currency, which just might make the dream of a fully digital currency real. Crypto got off to a very rocky start, but that just may be a good thing, because it’s helping to iron out the bugs before it goes mainstream. Drones: Again, already here. Drones are empowered by advances in batteries & computers, just like electric vehicles. Expect to see more drones - and more uses for drones - in the next decade. I’m not sure if we’ll see them delivering packages anytime soon, but I’d bet they’ll rapidly become a staple for photography at all manner of events, from weddings to graduations. Everything Goes Wireless (Again): Wifi 6 is coming out, which allows more devices, more wireless, faster bandwidth, etc. The same is true in the cellular world with 5G technology - which promises to increase speed & reduce latency and basically make your cellphone work like it’s on WiFi all of the time. ~ A Bit Further Out ~ A Cure For Aging? Harvard geneticist David Sinclair claims his team been reversing the aging of mice in the lab for around 3 years now by using NMN to boost NAD levels. We probably won’t have to wait for human trials, because a sister compound Nicotimade Riboside is selling like crazy on the Internet under the brand name Niagen®. Mainstream Quantum Computing? In 2016 IBM added a Quantum Computer to the cloud - letting anyone with an internet connection design & test their own quantum circuits. I don’t expect to see Quantum Computers in the home during the upcoming decade, but we’ll definitely be seeing & hearing more about them in the 2020’s. Fusion Energy? There’s a LOT going on in fusion research right now - too much for me to cover here. New ideas & technologies, combined with much faster computer modeling, might just give us a fusion breakthrough in the next decade - but don’t hold your breath. Climate Change: Greenhouse gas emissions need to be cut in half by 2030 to avoid a 3 degree Centigrade increase in global average temperature. Or else. I’m guessing that the already worsening effects of climate change will inspire more action on this in the 2020’s, and if people really get motivated it may lead to changes in many other areas, such as an intensified push for renewable materials & alternative energies. Humans On Mars? There’s lots of work being done in this area, but it’s going to be a big endeavor with a lot of unknowns. Elon Musk seems to think we can get there in the mid-2020’s, so maybe? Keep your fingers crossed…

2020, Are you(2020) for real…???🙄🙄🙄 It's almost scary that it's just the fifth month and I already need a new year. Isn't this full of surprises?  It was just in January that we were happy and cheerful about the new beginnings, and how you might bring us a big break in our lives – love, career, and peace. But, you are one hell of a roller coaster ride which only goes down, and none of us know how deep your pit really is. 3 months in and you're already on fire. Literally. Every month you keep escalating almost as if you're taking a payback for things we've done. From state issues to national issues and now international emergency with all the protests, pandemic and so much more; the world has stopped moving. Almost… I can go on and on about how many lives are on stake and how many families are already broke for the misery you brought upon us, but I want to tell you that this war which you've started, we are going to finish it. Together… No matter how hard you push us to the ground, today the world stands together, against all your endeavours to tear us apart…Because if anything else, you've united us with humanity, and our faith, power will survive this as one.None of us know what else you have in your corner for the time we've left between us, but for one, I know we're coming out of this stronger and better.👊👊👊 So, maybe I'll be thankful for you… Because nothing stays forever, and as a friend told this to me one day, I know - "This too shall pass…” Thank you ...☺️☺️☺️

There seems to be two types of responses to this question. One assumes a blase attitude as if nothing special is happening in the world. The other invokes a rather serious view of the future, in which myriad different strands are coalescing into a major paradigm shift. I hold the latter opinion. Currently COVID19 is consuming the news cycle. But it is connected at its base with two other major other issues. One is Global Warming, whereby global heating has changed the balance of nature such that viruses (and other life forms) are no longer in a state of balance and anomalous outbreaks of diseases deadly to humans have mutated and become direct threats to our society’s continuance. The other major threat is the rise of Nationalism and authoritarianism as exemplified by Trump , Putin , Erdoğan, Orban and others. Together we can either address and remedy these bad situations, or we can ignore and accept them. Either way, 2020 is likely to be a major event in human history. Or the beginning of its end.

Well, we can’t know for sure. So, what is your question? Do you want a best-case scenario?Do you want a worst-case scenario?Do you want an average expectation? Maybe you are thinking of specific aspects of “the world”. Do you want to know about our course on climate change?Do you want to know about the electoral collage “situation”?Do you want to know about education and what we will have to offer to future generations? Really, each of these should deserve their own questions and answers.  What about our changing values and how we will act upon them? I recommend this article by Dave Pell on how our ignorance and fear of standing up for our values has done so much harm in the past - and now:The Looking Glass – Dave Pell – Medium I recommend this article by Dave Pell on how our values did not change but also how they are challenged and therefore clarified:Allow Me to Clarify – Dave Pell – Medium And I think that our society will go through a massive transformation concerning how we organize and communicate around our values. This may or may not happen until 2020, but it probably will happen.

If I could predict accurately and in detai, I could get rich (and buy myself a new car). Since I can't, I can only speculate and guess. Therefore I think: It will be a circus. 2018–2020 will be filled with extremism, outrageous partisanship, economic pot holes, violence in the streets — in short, pretty much what we have now. BUT two factors will make it all much worse: tech's attempts to control the conversation and favor their candidates & a whole gaggle of Dems desperate to slay the dragon. This will include Kamala and Kirsten (the Xena pair), Cory and Joe (Spartacus and the Toucher), Bernie and Schultz (the Spender and the Barista), and untold dozens of ambitious liberals who think a chance like running against someone like Trump only comes along once in a lifetime. If our Republic survives to 2020, it will only be by the grace of God.

Upheaval, loss, restoration, and resilience. Looks to me as if we’re in for a massive and thorough turn-out of old forms that developed, worked, and carried us (humanity, by my particular view is as a westerner) through to the point where they barely work at all any more, being riddled with senescence, corruption, and hide-bound notions framed in a very different time. Drastic change has been brought on by our childishly exuberant and wasteful ways; we’re going to have to make some similarly drastic social and economic changes to survive, and then to cope with our changed circumstances. Our strength as a species has been our adaptability — we have remained generalists, instead of specializing in big predatory teeth and claws, or extra stomachs to digest grass, or wings, or prehensile tails. We can become whatever we need to; the question is one of will. At issue is our survival as a dominant (in terms of our world) species, or perhaps as a species at all. I think we need to look forward more than we need to look back. That’s our “singularity”, IMO. When we do have time and energy to spare for looking back at what will undoubtedly be seen by many as a “golden age”, it will be across an unbridgeable canyon of change. In other words, very very very interesting times.

About the same. A few more gadgets and geedunks, some new structures, quite a few more people and somewhat fewer wild creatures, but on the whole the world will be a place neither breathtakingly incomprehensible nor significantly deteriorated. The major exception would be natural disasters and their consequences. For example, the undersea earthquake off of northern Japan, the resulting tsunami, the flooding and destruction of the Fukushima nuclear power plant, and destruction of cities, villages, and shoreline over hundreds of miles, has made Japan a very different place. If the long-anticipated volcanic eruption under Yellowstone Park should occur before 2020, much of the world would look quite different. A large asteroid striking anywhere on the earth would change things greatly. And so on, for many types of natural disasters. Otherwise, we will probably see a world in 2020 not much changed from today.

Globally this year would be very challenging. While analyzing planetary transits through the year of 2020 we find that Jupiter will be entering Capricorn by end March and again will become retro and move back into Sagittarius. Later Jupiter will again become direct in motion and enter Capricorn by Nov 2020. There will be a lot of financial confusions and chaos in market this year. People who are in a stable job should not try to change a job. Better not experiment this year with regard to investments. The seasons are also going to be rough. The summer will be hot, the windy season of Jyestha will be very windy with gusty winds. Since it is the beginning of the Rainy season there will be rain and windy thunderstorms. People who live in hilly areas and those areas which are near to the shore line are susceptible to damage and calamity. The financial market will waver and will pose difficulty to normal investors. In particular the time between June and July will be tough (because of double retrogression of Jupiter, Saturn and also due to the 21st June Solar eclipse which will run along the northern part of India). Students will do well in their studies. It will be normal with newly married couples. Some areas of India will have good crops due to copious rain.

Question: What will this world look like in 2020? Answer: My guess is as good as yours. And secondly, we are already in mid 2016. It is just 3 1/2 more years. I don’t think there would be much of a change. But it is almost impossible to predict about the future. When Soviet Union began after WW I, no body expected it would end within 75 years. I know there were some who predicted about the unsustainability of the economic model of Soviet Union, such as Soviet dissident Mr. Andrei Amalrik, Frenchman, Mr. Emmanuel Todd, economist Mr. Ravi Batra and the author of 1984, Mr. George Orwell. Apparently Soviet government told in 1984, that the predicted time of collapse, 1984 had passed but the Soviet Union still continued. But in 1991, it eventually collapsed. Similarly, I don’t think there was any prediction about Arab Spring. (I’m not considering the astrological predictions of Nostradamus). We can generally assume that authoritarian regimes will face huge resistance sometimes and collapse. Perhaps it will happen in China and a few other authoritarian regimes, sometime in future.

I think unemployment rate will get worse. As for positives of the Democrats do take the election I think we could see a trend in better healthcare reform and foreign relations. I think the food industry will trend upwards with more people wanting organic food. Overall though I think we won’t see much of difference. 2020 will probably be just as bad as it has always been.

We cannot know the future, but presently it seems that so much is politics. I have tried a bit to spread the word that prosperity and well-being are best achieved by following the concepts in the US Declaration of Independence and the Constitution. That is liberty, freedom, incentives and power with the people going up, instead of power going down from the government. No where is democracy mentioned. The people can be swayed into action like a mob, thus the divisions of power in the government were meant to make changes take time and contemplation. 2020 needs to be a period when actions are studied before making judgements. Presently, there is a lot of shouting about lies and misinformation. If this gets the majority into thinking like a mob, the US could get on the same slope that has hit all the nations that have tried socialism, with Venezuela being the latest. In any area of complexity, one can find true facts that support any point of view. We all make choices and then the choices make us.

But if another pawn of the establishment such as Chuck Schoomer or Nancy Pelosi is the other candidate then yeah, four more years of Trump. 2020 is also the year of the next census though the 2020 congressional elections will run on data from the 2010 census.

Embrace it or be on the wrong side of history.

More widely, there is likely to be more wild weather.  And perhaps no significant economic recovery in the West.

Since Economics is not science, nobody is able to accurately predict how our economy will perform. Since economy is the main driver of all of our comforts of living, it’s an important issue and concern, but there is no way to predict our economic future. However, having said all that, our country is now in the longest economic expansion in history, and that in of itself is reassuring. Our GDP growth at around 2% per year is healthy according to Economists, and I agree.

Your will find meaning of your life when you find your “uniqueness”. You were born for certain skills or tasks which help you find your uniqueness, which in turn help you become part of serving this world in a positive way. Meaning of life has always been same since the inception of mankind. It’s the way how you make it meaningful has been changed or keeps changing throughout your life.

First, take a deep breath. If you’re just waking up to the possibility there are terrible things out there, capable of wiping out life as we know it, well, you’re learning. I would suggest you spend more time, studying history. Then, work on not wasting the life you’ve been given. It’s a lot more rewarding than trying to create an impossible utopia, or living in fear of how you’re going to die and doing nothing.
